SCENE.STAGEDIR: A tempeſtuous noiſe of Thunder and Lightning heard: Enter a Ship-maſter, and a Boteſwaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maſter.
SPEECH.LINE: Bote-ſwaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Maſter: What cheere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Good: Speake to th’Mariners: fall
too’t, yarely, or we run our ſelues a ground,
beſtirre, beſtirre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Heigh my hearts, cheerely, cheerely my harts:
yare, yare: Take in the toppe-ſale: Tend to th’Maſters
whiſtle: Blow till thou burſt thy winde, if roome e-
nough.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alonſo, Sebaſtian, Anthonio, Ferdinando, Gonzalo, and others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Boteſwaine haue care: where’s the Ma-
ſter? Play the men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray now keepe below.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the Maſter, Boſon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you not heare him? you marre our labour,
Keepe your Cabines: you do aſsiſt the ſtorme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good be patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: When the Sea is: hence, what cares theſe roa-
rers for the name of King? to Cabine; ſilence: trouble
vs not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Good, yet remember whom thou haſt aboord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: None that I more loue then my ſelfe. You are
a Counſellor, if you can command theſe Elements to ſi-
lence, and worke the peace of the preſent, wee will not
hand a rope more, vſe your authoritie: If you cannot,
giue thankes you haue liu’d ſo long, and make your
ſelfe readie in your Cabine for the miſchance of the
houre, if it ſo hap. Cheerely good hearts: out of our
way I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue great comfort from this fellow: methinks
he hath no drowning marke vpon him, his complexion
is perfeƈt Gallowes: ſtand faſt good Fate to his han-
ging, make the rope of his deſtiny our cable, for our
owne doth little aduantage: If he be not borne to bee
hang’d, our caſe is miſerable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Downe with the top-Maſt: yare, lower, lower,
bring her to Try with Maine-courſe. A plague —
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: A cry within. Enter Sebaſtian, Anthonio & Gonzalo.
SPEECH.LINE: vpon this howling: they are lowder then the weather,
or our office: yet againe? What do you heere? Shal we
giue ore and drowne, haue you a minde to ſinke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sebaſ.
SPEECH.LINE: A poxe o’your throat, you bawling, blaſphe-
mous incharitable Dog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Worke you then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang cur, hang, you whoreſon inſolent Noyſe-
maker, we are leſſe afraid to be drownde, then thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: I’le warrant him for drowning, though the
Ship were no ſtronger then a Nutt-ſhell, and as leaky as
an vnſtanched wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay her a hold, a hold, ſet her two courſes off
to Sea againe, lay her off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mari.
SPEECH.LINE: All loſt, to prayers, to prayers, all loſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boteſ.
SPEECH.LINE: What muſt our mouths be cold?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: The King, and Prince, at prayers, let’s aſſiſt them,
for our caſe is as theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sebaſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I’am out of patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: We are meerly cheated of our liues by drunkards,
This wide-chopt-raſcall, would thou mightſt lye drow-
ning the waſhing of ten Tides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee’l be hang’d yet,
Though euery drop of water ſweare againſt it,
And gape at widſt to glut him. A confuſed noyſe within.
Mercy on vs.
We ſplit, we ſplit, Farewell my wife, and children,
Farewell brother: we ſplit, we ſplit, we ſplit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s all ſinke with’ King

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s take leaue of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Now would I giue a thouſand furlongs of Sea,
for an Acre of barren ground: Long heath, Browne
firrs, any thing; the wills aboue be done, but I would
faine dye a dry death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: If by your Art (my deereſt father) you haue
Put the wild waters in this Rore; alay them:
The skye it ſeemes would powre down ſtinking pitch,
But that the Sea, mounting to th’ welkins cheeke,
Daſhes the fire out. Oh! I haue ſuffered
With thoſe that I ſaw ſuffer: A braue veſſell
(Who had no doubt ſome noble creature in her)
Daſh’d all to peeces: O the cry did knocke
Againſt my very heart: poore ſoules, they periſh’d.
Had I byn any God of power, I would
Haue ſuncke the Sea within the Earth, or ere
It ſhould the good Ship ſo haue ſwallow’d, and
The fraughting Soules within her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Be colleƈted,
No more amazement: Tell your pitteous heart
there’s no harme done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O woe, the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: No harme:
I haue done nothing, but in care of thee
(Of thee my deere one; thee my daughter) who
Art ignorant of what thou art. naught knowing
Of whence I am: nor that I am more better
Then Proſpero, Maſter of a full poore cell,
And thy no greater Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: More to know
Did neuer medle with my thoughts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis time
I ſhould informe thee farther: Lend thy hand
And plucke my Magick garment from me: So,
Lye there my Art: wipe thou thine eyes, haue comfort,
The direfull ſpectacle of the wracke which touch’d
The very vertue of compaſſion in thee:
I haue with ſuch prouiſion in mine Art
So ſafely ordered, that there is no ſoule
No not ſo much perdition as an hayre
Betid to any creature in the veſſell
Which thou heardſt cry, which thou ſaw’ſt ſinke: Sit downe,
For thou muſt now know farther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue often
Begun to tell me what I am, but ſtopt
And left me to a booteleſſe Inquiſition,
Concluding, ſtay: not yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: The howr’s now come
The very minute byds thee ope thine eare,
Obey, and be attentiue. Canſt thou remember
A time before we came vnto this Cell?
I doe not thinke thou canſt, for then thou was’t not
Out three yeeres old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Certainely Sir, I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: By what? by any other houſe, or perſon?
Of any thing the Image, tell me, that
Hath kept with thy remembrance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis farre off:
And rather like a dreame, then an aſſurance
That my remembrance warrants: Had I not
Fowre, or fiue women once, that tended me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hadſt; and more Miranda: But how is it
That this liues in thy minde? What ſeest thou els
In the dark-backward and Abiſme of Time?
Yf thou remembreſt ought ere thou cam’ſt here,
How thou cam’ſt here thou maiſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: But that I doe not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Twelue yere ſince (Miranda) twelue yere ſince,
Thy father was the Duke of Millaine and
A Prince of power:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, are not you my Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Mother was a peece of vertue, and
She ſaid thou waſt my daughter; and thy father
Was Duke of Millaine, and his onely heire,
And Princeſſe; no worſe Iſſued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O the heauens,
What fowle play had we, that we came from thence?
Or bleſſed was’t we did?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Both, both my Girle.
By fowle-play (as thou ſaiſt) were we heau’d thence,
But bleſſedly holpe hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O my heart bleedes
To thinke oth’ teene that I haue turn’d you to,
Which is from my remembrance, pleaſe you, farther;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My brother and thy vncle, call’d Anthonio:
I pray thee marke me, that a brother ſhould
Be ſo perfidious: he, whom next thy ſelfe
Of all the world I lou’d, and to him put
The mannage of my ſtate, as at that time
Through all the ſignories it was the firſt,
And Proſpero, the prime Duke, being ſo reputed
In dignity; and for the liberall Artes,
Without a paralell; thoſe being all my ſtudie,
The Gouernment I caſt vpon my brother,
And to my State grew ſtranger, being tranſported
And rapt in ſecret ſtudies, thy falſe vncle
(Do’ſt thou attend me?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, moſt heedefully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Being once perfeƈted how to graunt ſuites,
how to deny them: who t’aduance, and who
To traſh for ouer-topping; new created
The creatures that were mine, I ſay, or chang’d ’em,
Or els new form’d ’em; hauing both the key,
Of Officer, and office, ſet all hearts i’th ſtate
To what tune pleas’d his eare, that now he was
The Iuy which had hid my princely Trunck,
And ſuckt my verdure out on’t: Thou attend’ſt not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O good Sir, I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee marke me:
I thus negleƈting worldly ends, all dedicated
To cloſenes, and the bettering of my mind
with that, which but by being ſo retir’d
Ore-priz’d all popular rate: in my falſe brother
Awak’d an euill nature, and my truſt
Like a good parent, did beget of him
A falſehood in it’s contrarie, as great
As my truſt was, which had indeede no limit,
A confidence ſans bound. He being thus Lorded,
Not onely with what my reuenew yeelded,
But what my power might els exaƈt. Like one
Who hauing into truth, by telling of it,
Made ſuch a ſynner of his memorie
To credite his owne lie, he did beleeue
He was indeed the Duke, out o’th’ Subſtitution
And executing th’outward face of Roialtie
With all prerogatiue: hence his Ambition growing:
Do’ſt thou heare ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Your tale, Sir, would cure deafeneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: To haue no Schreene between this part he plaid,
And him he plaid it for, he needes will be
Abſolute Millaine, Me (poore man) my Librarie
Was Dukedome large enough: of temporall roalties
He thinks me now incapable. Confederates
(ſo drie he was for Sway) with King of Naples
To giue him Annuall tribute, doe him homage
Subieƈt his Coronet, to his Crowne and bend
The Dukedom yet vnbow’d (alas poore Millaine)
To moſt ignoble ſtooping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh the heauens:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke his condition, and th’euent, then tell me
If this might be a brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould ſinne
To thinke but Noblie of my Grand-mother,
Good wombes haue borne bad ſonnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the Condition.
This King of Naples being an Enemy
To me inueterate, hearkens my Brothers ſuit,
Which was, That he in lieu o’th’ premiſes,
Of homage, and I know not how much Tribute,
Should preſently extirpate me and mine
Out of the Dukedome, and confer faire Millaine
With all the Honors, on my brother: Whereon
A treacherous Armie leuied, one mid-night
Fated to th’ purpoſe, did Anthonio open
The gates of Millaine, and ith’ dead of darkeneſſe
The miniſters for th’ purpoſe hurried thence
Me, and thy crying ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alack, for pitty:
I not remembring how I cride out then
Will cry it ore againe: it is a hint
That wrings mine eyes too’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare a little further,
And then I’le bring thee to the preſent buſineſſe
Which now’s vpon’s: without the which, this Story
Were moſt impertinent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore did they not
That howre deſtroy vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well demanded, wench:
My Tale prouokes that queſtion: Deare, they durſt not,
So deare the loue my people bore me: nor ſet
A marke ſo bloudy on the buſineſſe; but
With colours fairer, painted their foule ends.
In few, they hurried vs a-boord a Barke,
Bore vs ſome Leagues to Sea, where they prepared
A rotten carkaſſe of a Butt, not rigg’d,
Nor tackle, ſayle, nor maſt, the very rats
Inſtinƈtiuely haue quit it: There they hoyſt vs
To cry to th’ Sea, that roard to vs; to ſigh
To th’ windes, whoſe pitty ſighing backe againe
Did vs but louing wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alack, what trouble
Was I then to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: O, a Cherubin
Thou was’t that did preſerue me; Thou didſt ſmile,
Infuſed with a fortitude from heauen,
When I haue deck’d the ſea with drops full ſalt,
Vnder my burthen groan’d, which raiſ’d in me
An vndergoing ſtomacke, to beare vp
Againſt what ſhould enſue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: How came we a ſhore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: By prouidence diuine,
Some food, we had, and ſome freſh water, that
A noble Neopolitan Gonzalo
Out of his Charity, (who being then appointed
Maſter of this deſigne) did giue vs, with
Rich garments, linnens, ſtuffs, and neceſſaries
Which ſince haue ſteeded much, ſo of his gentleneſſe
Knowing I lou’d my bookes, he furniſhd me
From mine owne Library, with volumes, that
I prize aboue my Dukedome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I might
But euer ſee that man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Now I ariſe,
Sit ſtill, and heare the laſt of our ſea-sorrow:
Heere in this Iland we arriu’d, and heere
Haue I, thy SchooleMaſter, made thee more profit
Then other Princeſſe can, that haue more time
For vainer howres; and Tutors, not ſo carefull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Heuens thank you for’t. And now I pray you Sir,
For ſtill ’tis beating in my minde; your reaſon
For rayſing this Sea-ſtorme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Know thus far forth,
By accident moſt ſtrange, bountifull Fortune
(Now my deere Lady) hath mine enemies
Brought to this ſhore: And by my preſcience
I finde my Zenith doth depend vpon
A moſt auſpitious ſtarre, whoſe influence
If now I court not, but omit; my fortunes
Will euer after droope: Heare ceaſe more queſtions,
Thou art inclinde to ſleepe: ’tis a good dulneſſe,
And giue it way: I know thou canſt not chuſe:
Come away, Seruant, come; I am ready now,
Approach my Ariel. Come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ari.
SPEECH.LINE: All haile, great Maſter, graue Sir, haile: I come
To anſwer thy beſt pleaſure; be’t to fly,
To ſwim, to diue into the fire: to ride
On the curld clowds: to thy ſtrong bidding, taske
Ariel, and all his Qualitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Haſt thou, Spirit,
Performd to point, the Tempeſt that I bad thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: To euery Article.
I boorded the Kings ſhip: now on the Beake,
Now in the Waſte, the Decke, in euery Cabyn,
I flam’d amazement, ſometime I’ld diuide
And burne in many places; on the Top-maſt,
The Yards and Bore-ſpritt, would I flame diſtinƈtly,
Then meete, and ioyne. Ioues Lightning, the precurſers
O’th dreadfull Thunder-claps more momentarie
And ſight out-running were not; the fire, and cracks
Of ſulphurous roaring, the moſt mighty Neptune
Seeme to beſiege, and make his bold waues tremble,
Yea, his dread Trident ſhake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My braue Spirit,
Who was ſo firme, ſo conſtant, that this coyle
Would not infeƈt his reaſon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a ſoule
But felt a Feauer of the madde, and plaid
Some tricks of deſperation; all but Mariners
Plung’d in the foaming bryne, and quit the veſſell;
Then all a fire with me the Kings ſonne Ferdinand
With haire vp-ſtaring (then like reeds, not haire)
Was the firſt man that leapt; cride hell is empty,
And all the Diuels are heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s my ſpirit:
But was not this nye ſhore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Cloſe by, my Maſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But are they (Ariell) ſafe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a haire periſhd:
On their ſuſtaining garments not a blemiſh,
But freſher then before: and as thou badſt me,
In troops I haue diſperſd them ’bout the Iſle:
The Kings ſonne haue I landed by himſelfe,
Whom I left cooling of the Ayre with ſighes,
In an odde Angle of the Iſle, and ſitting
His armes in this ſad knot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Of the Kings ſhip,
The Marriners, ſay how thou haſt diſpoſd,
And all the reſt o’th’ Fleete?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Safely in harbour
Is the Kings ſhippe, in the deepe Nooke, where once
Thou calldſt me vp at midnight to fetch dewe
From the ſtill-vext Bermoothes, there ſhe’s hid;
The Marriners all vnder hatches ſtowed,
Who, with a Charme ioynd to their ſuffred labour
I haue left aſleep: and for the reſt o’th’ Fleet
(Which I diſperſ’d) they all haue met againe,
And are vpon the Mediterranian Flote
Bound ſadly home for Naples,
Suppoſing that they ſaw the Kings ſhip wrackt,
And his great perſon periſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ariel, thy charge
Exaƈtly is perform’d; but there’s more worke:
What is the time o’th’ day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Paſt the mid ſeason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: At leaſt two Glaſſes: the time ’twixt ſix & now
Muſt by vs both be ſpent moſt preciouſly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there more toyle? Since ӳ doſt giue me pains,
Let me remember thee what thou haſt promis’d,
Which is not yet perform’d me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? moodie?
What is’t thou canſt demand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: My Libertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Before the time be out? no more:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee,
Remember I haue done thee worthy ſeruice,
Told thee no lyes, made thee no miſtakings, ſerv’d
Without or grudge, or grumblings; thou did promiſe
To bate me a full yeere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Do’ſt thou forget
From what a torment I did free thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do’ſt: & thinkſt it much to tread ý Ooze
Of the ſalt deepe;
To run vpon the ſharpe winde of the North,
To doe me buſineſſe in the veines o’th’ earth
When it is bak’d with froſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe not Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lieſt, malignant Thing: haſt thou forgot
The fowle Witch Sycorax, who with Age and Enuy
Was growne into a hoope? haſt thou forgot her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: No Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou haſt: where was ſhe born? ſpeak: tell me:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, in Argier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, was ſhe ſo: I muſt
Once in a moneth recount what thou haſt bin,
Which thou forgetſt. This damn’d Witch Sycorax
For miſchiefes manifold, and ſorceries terrible
To enter humane hearing, from Argier
Thou know’ſt was baniſh’d: for one thing ſhe did
They wold not take her life: Is not this true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: This blew ey’d hag, was hither brought with child,
And here was left by th’ Saylors; thou my ſlaue,
As thou reportſt thy ſelfe, was then her ſeruant,
And for thou waſt a Spirit too delicate
To aƈt her earthy, and abhord commands,
Refuſing her grand heſts, ſhe did confine thee
By helpe of her more potent Miniſters,
And in her moſt vnmittigable rage,
Into a clouen Pyne, within which rift
Impriſon’d, thou didſt painefully remaine
A dozen yeeres: within which ſpace ſhe di’d,
And left thee there: where thou didſt vent thy groanes
As faſt as Mill-wheeles ſtrike: Then was this Iſland
(Saue for the Son, that he did littour heere,
A frekelld whelpe, hag-borne) not honour’d with
A humane ſhape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes: Caliban her ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Dull thing, I ſay ſo: he, that Caliban
Whom now I keepe in ſeruice, thou beſt know’ſt
What torment I did finde thee in; thy grones
Did make wolues howle, and penetrate the breaſts
Of euer-angry Beares; it was a torment
To lay vpon the damn’d, which Sycorax
Could not againe vndoe: it was mine Art,
When I arriu’d, and heard thee, that made gape
The Pyne, and let thee out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee Maſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou more murmur’ſt, I will rend an Oake
And peg-thee in his knotty entrailes, till
Thou haſt howl’d away twelue winters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, Maſter,
I will be correſpondent to command
And doe my ſpryting, gently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe ſo: and after two daies
I will diſcharge thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s my noble Maſter:
What ſhall I doe? ſay what? what ſhall I doe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe make thy ſelfe like a Nymph o’th’ Sea,
Be ſubieƈt to no ſight but thine, and mine: inuiſible
To euery eye-ball elſe: goe take this ſhape
And hither come in’t: goe: hence
With diligence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Awake, deere hart awake, thou haſt ſlept well,
Awake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtrangenes of your ſtory, put
Heauineſſe in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Shake it off: Come on,
Wee’ll viſit Caliban, my ſlaue, who neuer
Yeelds vs kinde anſwere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis a villaine Sir, I doe not loue to looke on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But as ’tis
We cannot miſſe him: he do’s make our fire,
Fetch in our wood, and ſerues in Offices
That profit vs: What hoa: ſlaue: Caliban:
Thou Earth, thou: ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal. within.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s wood enough within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Come forth I ſay, there’s other buſines for thee:
Come thou Tortoys, when?
Fine appariſion: my queint Ariel,
Hearke in thine eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, it ſhall be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou poyſonous ſlaue, got by ý diuell himſelfe
Vpon thy wicked Dam; come forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: As wicked dewe, as ere my mother bruſh’d
With Rauens feather from vnwholeſome Fen
Drop on you both: A Southweſt blow on yee,
And bliſter you all ore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: For this be ſure, to night thou ſhalt haue cramps,
Side-ſtitches, that ſhall pen thy breath vp, Vrchins
Shall for that vaſt of night, that they may worke
All exerciſe on thee: thou ſhalt be pinch’d
As thicke as hony-combe, each pinch more ſtinging
Then Bees that made ’em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt eat my dinner:
This Iſland’s mine by Sycorax my mother,
Which thou tak’ſt from me: when thou cam’ſt firſt
Thou ſtroakſt me, & made much of me: wouldſt giue me
Water with berries in’t: and teach me how
To name the bigger Light, and how the leſſe
That burne by day, and night: and then I lou’d thee
And ſhew’d thee all the qualities o’th’ Iſle,
The freſh Springs, Brine-pits; barren place and fertill,
Curs’d be I that did ſo: All the Charmes
Of Sycorax: Toades, Beetles, Batts light on you:
For I am all the Subieƈts that you haue,
Which firſt was min owne King: and here you ſty-me
In this hard Rocke, whiles you doe keepe from me
The reſt o’th’ Iſland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou moſt lying ſlaue,
Whom ſtripes may moue, not kindnes: I haue vſ’d thee
(Filth as thou art) with humane care, and lodg’d thee
In mine owne Cell, till thou didſt ſeeke to violate
The honor of my childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ho, oh ho, would’t had bene done:
Thou didſt preuent me, I had peopel’d elſe
This Iſle with Calibans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Abhorred Slaue,
Which any print of goodneſſe wilt not take,
Being capable of all ill: I pittied thee,
Took pains to make thee ſpeak, taught thee each houre
One thing or other: when thou didſt not (Sauage)
Know thine owne meaning; but wouldſt gabble, like
A thing moſt brutiſh, I endow’d thy purpoſes
With words that made them knowne: But thy vild race
(Tho thou didſt learn) had that in’t, which good natures
Could not abide to be with; therefore waſt thou
Deſeruedly confin’d into this Rocke, who hadſt
Deſeru’d more then a priſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: You taught me Language, and my profit on’t
Is, I know how to curſe: the red-plague rid you
For learning me your language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Hag-seed, hence:
Fetch vs in Fewell, and be quicke thou’rt beſt
To anſwer other buſineſſe: ſhrug’ſt thou (Malice)
If thou negleƈtſt, or doſt vnwillingly
What I command, Ile racke thee with old Crampes,
Fill all thy bones with Aches, make thee rore,
That beaſts ſhall tremble at thy dyn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: No, ’pray thee.
I muſt obey, his Art is of ſuch pow’r,
It would controll my Dams god Setebos,
And make a vaſſaile of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: So ſlaue, hence.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Exit Cal. Enter Ferdinand & Ariel, inuiſible playing & ſinging.

SPEECH.LINE: Come vnto theſe yellow ſands,
and then take hands:
Curtſied when you haue, and kiſt
the wilde waues whiſt:
Foote it featly heere, and there, and ſweete Sprights beare
the burthen. Burthen diſperſedly.
Harke, harke, bowgh wawgh: the watch-Dogges barke,
bowgh-wawgh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, hark, I heare, the ſtraine of ſtrutting Chanticlere
cry cockadidle-dowe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſhold this Muſick be? I’th aire, or th’earth?
It ſounds no more: and ſure it waytes vpon
Some God o’th’ Iland, ſitting on a banke,
Weeping againe the King my Fathers wracke.
This Muſicke crept by me vpon the waters,
Allaying both their fury, and my paſſion
With it’s ſweet ayre: thence I haue follow’d it
(Or it hath drawne me rather) but ’tis gone.
No, it begins againe.
Full fadom fiue thy Father lies,
Of his bones are Corrall made:
Thoſe are pearles that were his eies,
Nothing of him that doth fade,
But doth ſuffer a Sea-change
Into ſomething rich, & ſtrange:
Sea-Nimphs hourly ring his knell.
Harke now I heare them, ding-dong bell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: The Ditty do’s remember my drown’d father,
This is no mortall buſines, nor no ſound
That the earth owes: I heare it now aboue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: The fringed Curtaines of thine eye aduance,
And ſay what thou ſee’ſt yond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: What is’t a Spirit?
Lord, how it lookes about: Beleeue me ſir,
It carries a braue forme. But ’tis a ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No wench, it eats, and ſleeps, & hath ſuch ſenſes
As we haue: ſuch. This Gallant which thou ſeeſt
Was in the wracke: and but hee’s ſomething ſtain’d
With greefe (that’s beauties canker) ӳ might’ſt call him
A goodly perſon: he hath loſt his fellowes,
And ſtrayes about to finde ’em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: I might call him
A thing diuine, for nothing naturall
I euer ſaw ſo Noble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: It goes on I ſee
As my ſoule prompts it: Spirit, fine ſpirit, Ile free thee
Within two dayes for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt ſure the Goddeſſe
On whom theſe ayres attend: Vouchſafe my pray’r
May know if you remaine vpon this Iſland,
And that you will ſome good inſtruƈtion giue
How I may beare me heere: my prime requeſt
(Which I do laſt pronounce) is (O you wonder)
If you be Mayd, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: No wonder Sir,
But certainly a Mayd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: My Language? Heauens:
I am the beſt of them that ſpeake this ſpeech,
Were I but where ’tis ſpoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: How? the beſt?
What wer’t thou if the King of Naples heard thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſingle thing, as I am now, that wonders
To heare thee ſpeake of Naples: he do’s heare me,
And that he do’s, I weepe: my ſelfe am Naples,
Who, with mine eyes (neuer ſince at ebbe) beheld
The King my Father wrack’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, for mercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes faith, & all his Lords, the Duke of Millaine
And his braue ſonne, being twaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke of Millaine
And his more brauer daughter, could controll thee
If now ’twere fit to do’t: At the firſt ſight
They haue chang’d eyes: Delicate Ariel,
Ile ſet thee free for this. A word good Sir,
I feare you haue done your ſelfe ſome wrong: A word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſpeakes my father ſo vngently? This
Is the third man that ere I ſaw: the firſt
That ere I ſigh’d for: pitty moue my father
To be enclin’d my way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: O, if a Virgin,
And your affeƈtion not gone forth, Ile make you
The Queene of Naples.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft ſir, one word more.
They are both in eythers pow’rs: But this ſwift buſines
I muſt vneaſie make, leaſt too light winning
Make the prize light. One word more: I charge thee
That thou attend me: Thou do’ſt heere vſurpe
The name thou ow’ſt not, and haſt put thy ſelfe
Vpon this Iſland, as a ſpy, to win it
From me, the Lord on’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No, as I am a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Ther’s nothing ill, can dwell in ſuch a Temple,
If the ill-ſpirit haue ſo fayre a houſe,
Good things will ſtriue to dwell with’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake not you for him: hee’s a Traitor: come,
Ile manacle thy necke and feete together:
Sea water ſhalt thou drinke: thy food ſhall be
The freſh-brooke Muſſels, wither’d roots, and huskes
Wherein the Acorne cradled. Follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No,
I will reſiſt ſuch entertainment, till
Mine enemy ha’s more pow’r.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He drawes, and is charmed from mouing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O deere Father,
Make not too raſh a triall of him, for
Hee’s gentle, and not fearfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: What I ſay,
My foote my Tutor? Put thy ſword vp Traitor,
Who mak’ſt a ſhew, but dar’ſt not ſtrike: thy conſcience
Is ſo poſſeſt with guilt: Come, from thy ward,
For I can heere diſarme thee with this ſticke,
And make thy weapon drop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Beſeech you Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence: hang not on my garments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir haue pity,
Ile be his ſurety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Silence: One word more
Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee: What,
An aduocate for an Impoſtor? Huſh:
Thou think’ſt there is no more ſuch ſhapes as he,
(Hauing ſeene but him and Caliban:) Fooliſh wench,
To th’moſt of men, this is a Caliban,
And they to him are Angels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: My affeƈtions
Are then moſt humble: I haue no ambition
To ſee a goodlier man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, obey:
Thy Nerues are in their infancy againe.
And haue no vigour in them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: So they are:
My ſpirits, as in a dreame, are all bound vp:
My Fathers loſſe, the weakneſſe which I feele,
The wracke of all my friends, nor this mans threats,
To whom I am ſubdude, are but light to me,
Might I but through my priſon once a day
Behold this Mayd: all corners elſe o’th’ Earth
Let liberty make vſe of: ſpace enough
Haue I in ſuch a prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: It workes: Come on.
Thou haſt done well, fine Ariell: follow me,
Harke what thou elſe ſhalt do mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Be of comfort,
My Fathers of a better nature (Sir)
Then he appeares by ſpeech: this is vnwonted
Which now came from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Proſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt be as free
As mountaine windes; but then exaƈtly do
All points of my command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: To th’ſyllable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros
SPEECH.LINE: Come follow: ſpeake not for him.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alonso, Sebaſtian, Anthonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Franciſco, and others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Beſeech you Sir, be merry; you haue cauſe,
(So haue we all) of ioy; for our eſcape
Is much beyond our loſſe; our hint of woe
Is common, euery day, ſome Saylors wife,
The Maſters of ſome Merchant, and the Merchant
Haue iuſt our Theame of woe: But for the miracle,
(I meane our preſeruation) few in millions
Can ſpeake like vs: then wiſely (good Sir) weigh
Our ſorrow, with our comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alons.
SPEECH.LINE: Prethee peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He receiues comfort like cold porredge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The Viſitor will not giue him ore ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke, hee’s winding vp the watch of his wit,
By and by it will ſtrike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: One: Tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: When euery greefe is entertaind,
That’s offer’d comes to th’entertainer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: A dollor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Dolour comes to him indeed, you haue ſpoken
truer then you purpoſ’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue taken it wiſelier then I meant you
ſhould.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, what a ſpend-thrift is he of his tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: I pre-thee ſpare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I haue done: But yet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He will be talking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Which, of he, or Adrian, for a good wager,
Firſt begins to crow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: The old Cocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The Cockrell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Done: The wager?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: A Laughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: A match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Though this Iſland ſeeme to be deſert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: So: you’r paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Vninhabitable, and almoſt inacceſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He could not miſſe’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: It muſt needs be of ſubtle, tender, and delicate
temperance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Temperance was a delicate wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and a ſubtle, as he moſt learnedly deliuer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: The ayre breathes vpon vs here moſt ſweetly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: As if it had Lungs, and rotten ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Or, as ’twere perfum’d by a Fen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is euery thing aduantageous to life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: True, ſaue meanes to liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Of that there’s none, or little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: How luſh and luſty the graſſe lookes?
How greene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The ground indeed is tawny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: With an eye of greene in’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He miſſes not much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: No: he doth but miſtake the truth totally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: But the rariety of it is, which is indeed almoſt
beyond credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: As many voucht rarieties are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: That our Garments being (as they were) drencht
in the Sea, hold notwithſtanding their freſhneſſe and
gloſſes, being rather new dy’de then ſtain’d with ſalte
water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: If but one of his pockets could ſpeake, would
it not ſay he lyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or very falſely pocket vp his report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes our garments are now as freſh as
when we put them on firſt in Affricke, at the marriage
of the kings faire daughter Claribel to the king of Tunis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twas a ſweet marriage, and we proſper well in
our returne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Tunis was neuer grac’d before with ſuch a Pa-
ragon to their Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſince widdow Dido’s time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Widow? A pox o’that: how came that Wid-
dow in? Widdow Dido!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What if he had ſaid Widdower Æneas too?
Good Lord, how you take it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Widdow Dido ſaid you? You make me ſtudy
of that: She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: This Tunis Sir was Carthage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I aſſure you Carthage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: His word is more then the miraculous Harpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath rais’d the wall, and houſes too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What impoſſible matter wil he make eaſy next?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke hee will carry this Iſland home in his
pocket, and giue it his ſonne for an Apple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſowing the kernels of it in the Sea, bring
forth more Iſlands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why in good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, we were talking, that our garments ſeeme
now as freſh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage
of your daughter, who is now Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And the rareſt that ere came there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Bate (I beſeech you) widdow Dido.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O Widdow Dido? I, Widdow Dido.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not Sir my doublet as freſh as the firſt day I
wore it? I meane in a ſort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſort was well fiſh’d for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: When I wore it at your daughters marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: You cram theſe words into mine eares, againſt
the ſtomacke of my ſenſe: would I had neuer
Married my daughter there: For comming thence
My ſonne is loſt, and (in my rate) ſhe too,
Who is ſo farre from Italy remoued,
I ne’re againe ſhall ſee her: O thou mine heire
Of Naples and of Millaine, what ſtrange fiſh
Hath made his meale on thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir he may liue,
I ſaw him beate the ſurges vnder him,
And ride vpon their backes; he trod the water
Whoſe enmity he flung aſide: and breſted
The ſurge moſt ſwolne that met him: his bold head
’Boue the contentious waues he kept, and oared
Himſelfe with his good armes in luſty ſtroke
To th’ſhore; that ore his waue-worne baſis bowed
As ſtooping to releeue him: I not doubt
He came aliue to Land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, hee’s gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir you may thank your ſelfe for this great loſſe,
That would not bleſſe our Europe with your daughter,
But rather looſe her to an Affrican,
Where ſhe at leaſt, is baniſh’d from your eye,
Who hath cauſe to wet the greefe on’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre-thee peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: You were kneel’d too, & importun’d otherwiſe
By all of vs: and the faire ſoule her ſelfe
Waigh’d betweene loathneſſe, and obedience, at
Which end o’th’beame ſhould bow: we haue loſt your ſon,
I feare for euer: Millaine and Naples haue
Mo widdowes in them of this buſineſſe making,
Then we bring men to comfort them:
The faults your owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: So is the deer’ſt oth’ loſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Sebaſtian,
The truth you ſpeake doth lacke ſome gentleneſſe,
And time to ſpeake it in: you rub the ſore,
When you ſhould bring the plaiſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And moſt Chirurgeonly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: It is foule weather in vs all, good Sir,
When you are cloudy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Fowle weather?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Very foule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Had I plantation of this Iſle my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee’d ſow’t vvith Nettle-seed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Or dockes, or Mallowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: And were the King on’t, what vvould I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Scape being drunke, for want of Wine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I’th’Commonwealth I vvould (by contraries)
Execute all things: For no kinde of Trafficke
Would I admit: No name of Magiſtrate:
Letters ſhould not be knowne: Riches, pouerty,
And vſe of ſeruice, none: Contraƈt, Succeſsion,
Borne, bound of Land, Tilth, Vineyard none:
No vſe of Mettall, Corne, or Wine, or Oyle:
No occupation, all men idle, all:
And Women too, but innocent and pure:
No Soueraignty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet he vvould be King on’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The latter end of his Common-wealth forgets
the beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: All things in common Nature ſhould produce
Without ſweat or endeuour: Treaſon, fellony,
Sword, Pike, Knife, Gun, or neede of any Engine
Would I not haue: but Nature ſhould bring forth
Of it owne kinde, all foyzon, all abundance
To feed my innocent people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: No marrying ’mong his ſubieƈts?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: None (man) all idle; Whores and knaues,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I vvould vvith ſuch perfeƈtion gouerne Sir:
T’Excell the Golden Age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Saue his Maiesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Long liue Gonzalo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: And do you marke me, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre-thee no more: thou doſt talke nothing to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I do vvell beleeue your Highneſſe, and did it
to miniſter occaſion to theſe Gentlemen, who are of
ſuch ſenſible and nimble Lungs, that they alwayes vſe
to laugh at nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twas you vve laugh’d at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, in this kind of merry fooling am nothing
to you: ſo you may continue, and laugh at nothing ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What a blow vvas there giuen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: And it had not falne flat-long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: You are Gentlemen of braue mettal: you would
lift the Moone out of her ſpheare, if ſhe would continue
in it fiue weekes vvithout changing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: We vvould ſo, and then go a Bat-fowling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay good my Lord, be not angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: No I warrant you, I vvill not aduenture my
diſcretion ſo weakly: Will you laugh me aſleepe, for I
am very heauy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſleepe, and heare vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: What, all ſo ſoone aſleepe? I wiſh mine eyes
Would (with themſelues) ſhut vp my thoughts,
I finde they are inclin’d to do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Pleaſe you Sir,
Do not omit the heauy offer of it:
It ſildome viſits ſorrow, when it doth, it is a Comforter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: We two my Lord, will guard your perſon,
While you take your reſt, and watch your ſafety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke you: Wondrous heauy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What a ſtrange drowſines poſſeſſes them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the quality o’th’Clymate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Why
Doth it not then our eye-lids ſinke? I finde
Not my ſelfe diſpos’d to ſleep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I, my ſpirits are nimble:
They fell together all, as by conſent
They dropt, as by a Thunder-ſtroke: what might
Worthy Sebaſtian? O, what might? no more:
And yet, me thinkes I ſee it in thy face,
What thou ſhould’ſt be: th’occasion ſpeaks thee, and
My ſtrong imagination ſee’s a Crowne
Dropping vpon thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What? art thou waking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you not heare me ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I do, and ſurely
It is a ſleepy Language; and thou ſpeak’ſt
Out of thy ſleepe: What is it thou didſt ſay?
This is a ſtrange repoſe, to be aſleepe
With eyes wide open: ſtanding, ſpeaking, mouing:
And yet ſo faſt aſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Sebaſtian,
Thou let’ſt thy fortune ſleepe: die rather: wink’ſt
Whiles thou art waking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do’ſt ſnore diſtinƈtly,
There’s meaning in thy ſnores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am more ſerious then my cuſtome: you
Muſt be ſo too, if heed me: which to do,
Trebbles thee o’re.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I am ſtanding water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile teach you how to flow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo: to ebbe
Hereditary Sloth inſtruƈts me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O!
If you but knew how you the purpoſe cheriſh
Whiles thus you mocke it: how in ſtripping it
You more inueſt it: ebbing men, indeed
(Moſt often) do ſo neere the bottome run
By their owne feare, or ſloth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Pre-thee ſay on,
The ſetting of thine eye, and cheeke proclaime
A matter from thee; and a birth, indeed,
Which throwes thee much to yeeld.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus Sir:
Although this Lord of weake remembrance; this
Who ſhall be of as little memory
When he is earth’d, hath here almoſt perſwaded
(For hee’s a Spirit of perſwaſion, onely
Profeſſes to perſwade) the King his ſonne’s aliue,
’Tis as impoſſible that hee’s vndrown’d,
As he that ſleepes heere, ſwims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no hope
That hee’s vndrown’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O, out of that no hope,
What great hope haue you? No hope that way, Is
Another way ſo high a hope, that euen
Ambition cannot pierce a winke beyond
But doubt diſcouery there. Will you grant with me
That Ferdinand is drown’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Then tell me, who’s the next heire of Naples?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Claribell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: She that is Queene of Tunis: ſhe that dwels
Ten leagues beyond mans life: ſhe that from Naples
Can haue no note, vnleſſe the Sun were poſt:
The Man i’th Moone’s too ſlow, till new-borne chinnes
Be rough, and Razor-able: She that from whom
We all were ſea-ſwallow’d, though ſome caſt againe,
(And by that deſtiny) to performe an aƈt
Whereof, what’s paſt is Prologue; what to come
In yours, and my diſcharge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſtuffe is this? How ſay you?
’Tis true my brothers daughter’s Queene of Tunis,
So is ſhe heyre of Naples, ’twixt which Regions
There is ſome ſpace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſpace, whoſe eu’ry cubit
Seemes to cry out, how ſhall that Claribell
Meaſure vs backe to Naples? keepe in Tunis,
And let Sebaſtian wake. Say, this were death
That now hath ſeiz’d them, why they were no worſe
Then now they are: There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that ſleepes: Lords, that can prate
As amply, and vnneceſſarily
As this Gonzallo: I my ſelfe could make
A Chough of as deepe chat: O, that you bore
The minde that I do; what a ſleepe were this
For your aduancement? Do you vnderſtand me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And how do’s your content
Tender your owne good fortune?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I remember
You did ſupplant your Brother Proſpero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: True:
And looke how well my Garments ſit vpon me,
Much feater then before: My Brothers ſeruants
Were then my fellowes, now they are my men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: But for your conſcience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir: where lies that? If ’twere a kybe
’Twould put me to my ſlipper: But I feele not
This Deity in my boſome: ’Twentie conſciences
That ſtand ’twixt me, and Millaine, candied be they,
And melt ere they molleſt: Heere lies your Brother,
No better then the earth he lies vpon,
If he were that which now hee’s like (that’s dead)
Whom I with this obedient ſteele (three inches of it)
Can lay to bed for euer: whiles you doing thus,
To the perpetuall winke for aye might put
This ancient morſell: this Sir Prudence, who
Should not vpbraid our courſe: for all the reſt
They’l take ſuggeſtion, as a Cat laps milke,
They’l tell the clocke, to any buſineſſe that
We ſay befits the houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy caſe, deere Friend
Shall be my preſident: As thou got’ſt Millaine,
I’le come by Naples: Draw thy ſword, one ſtroke
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou paieſt,
And I the King ſhall loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw together:
And when I reare my hand, do you the like
To fall it on Gonzalo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: O, but one word.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Ariell with Muſicke and Song.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariel.
SPEECH.LINE: My Maſter through his Art foreſees the danger
That you (his friend) are in, and ſends me forth
(For elſe his proieƈt dies) to keepe them liuing.
While you here do ſnoaring lie,
Open-ey’d Conſpiracie
His time doth take:
If of Life you keepe a care,
Shake off ſlumber and beware.
Awake, awake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let vs both be ſodaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, good Angels preſerue the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now hoa; awake? why are you drawn?
Wherefore this ghaſtly looking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Whiles we ſtood here ſecuring your repoſe,
(Euen now) we heard a hollow burſt of bellowing
Like Buls, or rather Lyons, did’t not wake you?
It ſtrooke mine eare moſt terribly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O, ’twas a din to fright a Monſters eare;
To make an earthquake: ſure it was the roare
Of a whole heard of Lyons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heard you this Gonzalo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine honour, Sir, I heard a humming,
(And that a ſtrange one too) which did awake me:
I ſhak’d you Sir, and cride: as mine eyes opend,
I ſaw their weapons drawne: there was a noyſe,
That’s verily: ’tis beſt we ſtand vpon our guard;
Or that we quit this place: let’s draw our weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead off this ground & let’s make further ſearch
For my poore ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens keepe him from theſe Beaſts:
For he is ſure i’th Iſland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Proſpero my Lord, ſhall know what I haue done.
So (King) goe ſafely on to ſeeke thy Son.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Caliban, with a burthen of Wood (a noyſe of Thunder heard.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: All the infeƈtions that the Sunne ſuckes vp
From Bogs, Fens, Flats, on Proſper fall, and make him
By ynch-meale a diſeaſe: his Spirits heare me,
And yet I needes muſt curſe. But they’ll nor pinch,
Fright me with Vrchyn-ſhewes, pitch me i’th mire,
Nor lead me like a fire-brand, in the darke
Out of my way, vnleſſe he bid ’em; but
For euery trifle, are they ſet vpon me,
Sometime like Apes, that moe and chatter at me,
And after bite me: then like Hedg-hogs, which
Lye tumbling in my bare-foote way, and mount
Their pricks at my foot-fall: ſometime am I
All wound with Adders, who with clouen tongues
Doe hiſſe me into madneſſe: Lo, now Lo, Enter Trinculo.
Here comes a Spirit of his, and to torment me
For bringing wood in ſlowly: I’le fall flat,
Perchance he will not minde me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Here’s neither buſh, nor ſhrub to beare off any
weather at all: and another Storme brewing, I heare it
ſing ith’ winde: yond ſame blacke cloud, yond huge
one, lookes like a foule bumbard that would ſhed his
licquor: if it ſhould thunder, as it did before, I know
not where to hide my head: yond ſame cloud cannot
chooſe but fall by paile-fuls. What haue we here, a man,
or a fiſh? dead or aliue? a fiſh, hee ſmels like a fiſh: a
very ancient and fiſh-like ſmell: a kinde of, not of the
neweſt poore-Iohn: a ſtrange fiſh: were I in England
now (as once I was) and had but this fiſh painted; not
a holiday-foole there but would giue a peece of ſiluer:
there, would this Monſter, make a man: any ſtrange
beaſt there, makes a man: when they will not giue a
doit to relieue a lame Begger, they will lay out ten to ſee
a dead Indian: Leg’d like a man; and his Finnes like
Armes: warme o’ my troth: I doe now let looſe my o-
pinion; hold it no longer; this is no fiſh, but an Iſlan-
der, that hath lately ſuffered by a Thunderbolt: Alas,
the ſtorme is come againe: my beſt way is to creepe vn-
der his Gaberdine: there is no other ſhelter herea-
bout: Miſery acquaints a man with ſtrange bedfel-
lowes: I will here ſhrowd till the dregges of the ſtorme
be paſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall no more to ſea, to ſea, here ſhall I dye aſhore.
This is a very ſcuruy tune to ſing at a mans
Funerall: well, here’s my comfort.
The Maſter, the Swabber, the Boate-ſwaine & I;
The Gunner, and his Mate
Lou’d Mall, Meg, and Marrian, and Margerie,
But none of vs car’d for Kate.
For ſhe had a tongue with a tang,
Would cry to a Sailor goe hang:
She lou’d not the ſauour of Tar nor of Pitch,
Yet a Tailor might ſcratch her where ere ſhe did itch.
Then to Sea Boyes, and let her goe hang.
This is a ſcuruy tune too:
But here’s my comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not torment me: oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s the matter?
Haue we diuels here?
Doe you put trickes vpon’s with Saluages, and Men of
Inde? ha? I haue not ſcap’d drowning, to be afeard
now of your foure legges: for it hath bin ſaid; as pro-
per a man as euer went on foure legs, cannot make him
giue ground: and it ſhall be ſaid ſo againe, while Ste-
phano breathes at’ noſtrils.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Spirit torments me: oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſome Monſter of the Iſle, with foure legs;
who hath got (as I take it) an Ague: where the diuell
ſhould he learne our language? I will giue him ſome re-
liefe if it be but for that: if I can recouer him, and keepe
him tame, and get to Naples with him, he’s a Pre-
ſent for any Emperour that euer trod on Neates-lea-
ther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not torment me ’prethee: I’le bring my
wood home faſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s in his fit now; and doe’s not talke after the
wiſeſt; hee ſhall taſte of my Bottle: if hee haue neuer
drunke wine afore, it will goe neere to remoue his Fit:
if I can recouer him, and keepe him tame, I will not take
too much for him; hee ſhall pay for him that hath him,
and that ſoundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do’ſt me yet but little hurt; thou wilt a-
non, I know it by thy trembling: Now Proſper workes
vpon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on your wayes: open your mouth: here
is that which will giue language to you Cat; open your
mouth; this will ſhake your ſhaking, I can tell you, and
that ſoundly: you cannot tell who’s your friend; open
your chaps againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould know that voyce:
It ſhould be,
But hee is dround; and theſe are diuels; O de-
fend me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Foure legges and two voyces; a moſt delicate
Monſter: his forward voyce now is to ſpeake well of
his friend; his backward voice, is to vtter foule ſpeeches,
and to detraƈt: if all the wine in my bottle will recouer
him, I will helpe his Ague: Come: Amen, I will
poure ſome in thy other mouth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Stephano.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy, mercy:
This is a diuell, and no Monſter: I will leaue him, I
haue no long Spoone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Stephano: if thou beeſt Stephano, touch me, and
ſpeake to me: for I am Trinculo; be not afeard, thy
good friend Trinculo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou bee’ſt Trinculo: come forth: I’le pull
thee by the leſſer legges: if any be Trinculo’s legges,
theſe are they: Thou art very Trinculo indeede: how
cam’ſt thou to be the ſiege of this Moone-calfe? Can
he vent Trinculo’s?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: I tooke him to be kil’d with a thunder-ſtrok; but
art thou not dround Stephano: I hope now thou art
not dround: Is the Storme ouer-blowne? I hid mee
vnder the dead Moone-Calfes Gaberdine, for feare of
the Storme: And art thou liuing Stephano? O Stephano,
two Neapolitanes ſcap’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Prethee doe not turne me about, my ſtomacke
is not conſtant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Theſe be fine things, and if they be not ſprights:
that’s a braue God, and beares Celeſtiall liquor: I will
kneele to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: How did’ſt thou ſcape?
How cam’ſt thou hither?
Sweare by this Bottle how thou cam’ſt hither: I eſcap’d
vpon a But of Sacke, which the Saylors heaued o’re-
boord, by this Bottle which I made of the barke of
a Tree, with mine owne hands, ſince I was caſt a’-
ſhore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I’le ſweare vpon that Bottle, to be thy true ſub-
ieƈt, for the liquor is not earthly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: St.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere: ſweare then how thou eſcap’dſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Swom ashore (man) like a Ducke: I can ſwim
like a Ducke i’le be ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, kiſſe the Booke.
Though thou canſt ſwim like a Ducke, thou art made
like a Gooſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: O Stephano, ha’ſt any more of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: The whole But (man) my Cellar is in a rocke
by th’ſea-ſide, where my Wine is hid:
How now Moone-Calfe, how do’s thine Ague?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha’ſt thou not dropt from heauen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Out o’th Moone I doe aſſure thee. I was the
Man ith’ Moone, when time was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſeene thee in her: and I doe adore thee:
My Miſtris ſhew’d me thee, and thy Dog, and thy Buſh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, ſweare to that: kiſſe the Booke: I will
furniſh it anon with new Contents: Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: By this good light, this is a very ſhallow Mon-
ſter: I afeard of him? a very weake Monſter:
The Man ith’ Moone?
A moſt poore creadulous Monſter:
Well drawne Monſter, in good ſooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſhew thee euery fertill ynch ’oth Iſland: and
I will kiſſe thy foote: I prethee be my god.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: By this light, a moſt perfidious, and drunken
Monſter, when’s god’s a ſleepe he’ll rob his Bottle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile kiſſe thy foot, Ile ſweare my ſelfe thy Subieƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on then: downe and ſweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall laugh my ſelfe to death at this puppi-hea-
ded Monſter: a moſt ſcuruie Monſter: I could finde in
my heart to beate him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: But that the poore Monſter’s in drinke:
An abhominable Monſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I’le ſhew thee the beſt Springs: I’le plucke thee
Berries: I’le fiſh for thee; and get thee wood enough.
A plague vpon the Tyrant that I ſerue;
I’le beare him no more Stickes, but follow thee, thou
wondrous man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: A moſt rediculous Monſter, to make a wonder of
a poore drunkard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ’prethee let me bring thee where Crabs grow;
and I with my long nayles will digge thee pig-nuts;
ſhow thee a Iayes neſt, and inſtruƈt thee how to ſnare
the nimble Marmazet: I’le bring thee to cluſtring
Philbirts, and ſometimes I’le get thee young Scamels
from the Rocke: Wilt thou goe with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I pre’thee now lead the way without any more
talking. Trinculo, the King, and all our company elſe
being dround, wee will inherit here: Here; beare my
Bottle: Fellow Trinculo; we’ll fill him by and by a-
gaine.
Farewell Maſter; farewell, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: A howling Monſter: a drunken Monſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: No more dams I’le make for fiſh,
Nor fetch in firing, at requiring,
Nor ſcrape trenchering, nor waſh diſh,
Ban’ ban’ Cacalyban
Has a new Maſter, get a new Man.
Freedome, high-day, high-day freedome, freedome high-
day, freedome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: O braue Monſter; lead the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: There be ſome Sports are painfull; & their labor
Delight in them ſet off: Some kindes of baſeneſſe
Are nobly vndergon; and moſt poore matters
Point to rich ends: this my meane Taske
Would be as heauy to me, as odious, but
The Miſtris which I ſerue, quickens what’s dead,
And makes my labours, pleaſures: O She is
Ten times more gentle, then her Father’s crabbed;
And he’s compos’d of harſhneſſe. I muſt remoue
Some thouſands of theſe Logs, and pile them vp,
Vpon a ſore iniunƈtion; my ſweet Miſtris
Weepes when ſhe ſees me worke, & ſaies, ſuch baſenes
Had neuer like Executor: I forget:
But theſe ſweet thoughts, doe euen refreſh my labours,
Moſt buſie leſt, when I doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, now pray you
Worke not ſo hard: I would the lightning had
Burnt vp thoſe Logs that you are enioynd to pile:
Pray ſet it downe, and reſt you: when this burnes
’Twill weepe for hauing wearied you: my Father
Is hard at ſtudy; pray now reſt your ſelfe,
Hee’s ſafe for theſe three houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: O moſt deere Miſtris
The Sun will ſet before I ſhall diſcharge
What I muſt ſtriue to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: If you’l ſit downe
Ile beare your Logges the while: pray giue me that,
Ile carry it to the pile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No precious Creature,
I had rather cracke my ſinewes, breake my backe,
Then you ſhould ſuch diſhonor vndergoe,
While I ſit lazy by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: It would become me
As well as it do’s you; and I ſhould do it
With much more eaſe: for my good will is to it,
And yours it is againſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore worme thou art infeƈted,
This viſitation ſhewes it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: You looke wearily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No, noble Miſtris, ’tis freſh morning with me
When you are by at night: I do beſeech you
Cheefely, that I might ſet it in my prayers,
What is your name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Miranda, O my Father,
I haue broke your heſt to ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Admir’d Miranda,
Indeede the top of Admiration, worth
What’s deereſt to the world: full many a Lady
I haue ey’d with beſt regard, and many a time
Th’harmony of their tongues, hath into bondage
Brought my too diligent eare: for ſeuerall vertues
Haue I lik’d ſeuerall women, neuer any
VVith ſo full ſoule, but ſome defeƈt in her
Did quarrell with the nobleſt grace ſhe ow’d,
And put it to the foile. But you, O you,
So perfeƈt, and ſo peetleſſe, are created
Of euerie Creatures beſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know
One of my ſexe; no womans face remember,
Saue from my glaſſe, mine owne: Nor haue I ſeene
More that I may call men, then you good friend,
And my deere Father: how features are abroad
I am ſkilleſſe of; but by my modeſtie
(The iewell in my dower) I would not wiſh
Any Companion in the world but you:
Nor can imagination forme a ſhape
Beſides your ſelfe, to like of: but I prattle
Something too wildely, and my Fathers precepts
I therein do forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: I am, in my condition
A Prince (Miranda) I do thinke a King
(I would not ſo) and would no more endure
This wodden ſlauerie, then to ſuffer
The fleſh-flie blow my mouth: heare my ſoule ſpeake.
The verie inſtant that I ſaw you, did
My heart flie to your ſeruice, there reſides
To make me ſlaue to it, and for your ſake
Am I this patient Logge-man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you loue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: O heauen; O earth, beare witnes to this ſound,
And crowne what I profeſſe with kinde euent
If I ſpeake true: if hollowly, inuert
VVhat beſt is boaded me, to miſchiefe: I,
Beyond all limit of what elſe i’th world
Do loue, prize, honor you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a foole
To weepe at what I am glad of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire encounter
Of two moſt rare affeƈtions: heauens raine grace
On that which breeds betweene ’em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: VVherefore weepe you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: At mine vnworthineſſe, that dare not offer
VVhat I deſire to giue; and much leſſe take
VVhat I ſhall die to want: But this is trifling,
And all the more it ſeekes to hide it ſelfe,
The bigger bulke it ſhewes. Hence baſhfull cunning,
And prompt me plaine and holy innocence.
I am your wife, if you will marrie me;
If not, Ile die your maid: to be your fellow
You may denie me, but Ile be your ſeruant
VVhether you will or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: My Miſtris (deereſt)
And I thus humble euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: My huſband then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: I, with a heart as willing
As bondage ere of freedome: heere’s my hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: And mine, with my heart in’t; and now farewel
Till halfe an houre hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: A thouſand, thouſand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: So glad of this as they I cannot be,
VVho are ſurpriz’d with all; but my reioycing
At nothing can be more: Ile to my booke,
For yet ere ſupper time, muſt I performe
Much buſineſſe appertaining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell not me, when the But is out we will drinke
water, not a drop before; therefore beare vp, & boord
em’ Seruant Monſter, drinke to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Seruant Monſter? the folly of this Iland, they
ſay there’s but fiue vpon this Iſle; we are three of them,
if th’other two be brain’d like vs, the State totters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Drinke ſeruant Monſter when I bid thee, thy
eies are almoſt ſet in thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: VVhere ſhould they bee ſet elſe? hee were a
braue Monſter indeede if they were ſet in his taile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: My man-Monſter hath drown’d his tongue in
ſacke: for my part the Sea cannot drowne mee, I ſwam
ere I could recouer the ſhore, fiue and thirtie Leagues
off and on, by this light thou ſhalt bee my Lieutenant
Monſter, or my Standard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lieutenant if you liſt, hee’s no ſtandard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: VVeel not run Monſieur Monſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor go neither: but you’l lie like dogs, and yet
ſay nothing neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Moone-calfe, ſpeak once in thy life, if thou beeſt
a good Moone-calfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: How does thy honour? Let me licke thy ſhooe:
Ile not ſerue him, he is not valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lieſt moſt ignorant Monſter, I am in caſe
to iuſtle a Conſtable: why, thou deboſh’d Fiſh thou,
was there euer man a Coward, that hath drunk ſo much
Sacke as I to day? wilt thou tell a monſtrous lie, being
but halfe a Fiſh, and halfe a Monſter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Loe, how he mockes me, wilt thou let him my
Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord, quoth he? that a Monſter ſhould be ſuch
a Naturall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Loe, loe againe: bite him to death I prethee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Trinculo, keepe a good tongue in your head: If
you proue a mutineere, the next Tree: the poore Mon-
ſter’s my ſubieƈt, and he ſhall not ſuffer indignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke my noble Lord. Wilt thou be pleas’d
to hearken once againe to the ſuite I made to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry will I: kneele, and repeate it,
I will ſtand, and ſo ſhall Trinculo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: As I told thee before, I am ſubieƈt to a Tirant,
A Sorcerer, that by his cunning hath cheated me
Of the Iſland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lyeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lyeſt, thou ieſting Monkey thou:
I would my valiant Maſter would deſtroy thee.
I do not lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in’s tale,
By this hand, I will ſupplant ſome of your teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I ſaid nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Mum then, and no more: proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay by Sorcery he got this Iſle
From me, he got it. If thy Greatneſſe will
Reuenge it on him, (for I know thou dar’ſt)
But this Thing dare not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s moſt certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt be Lord of it, and Ile ſerue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: How now ſhall this be compaſt?
Canſt thou bring me to the party?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, yea my Lord, Ile yeeld him thee aſleepe,
Where thou maiſt knocke a naile into his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lieſt, thou canſt not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: What a py’de Ninnie’s this? Thou ſcuruy patch:
I do beſeech thy Greatneſſe giue him blowes,
And take his bottle from him: When that’s gone,
He ſhall drinke nought but brine, for Ile not ſhew him
Where the quicke Freſhes are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Trinculo, run into no further danger:
Interrupt the Monſter one word further, and by this
hand, Ile turne my mercie out o’doores, and make a
Stockfiſh of thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what did I? I did nothing:
Ile go farther off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Didſt thou not ſay he lyed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lieſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Do I ſo? Take thou that,
As you like this, giue me the lye another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not giue the lie: Out o’your wittes, and
hearing too?
A pox o’your bottle, this can Sacke and drinking doo:
A murren on your Monſter, and the diuell take your
fingers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Now forward with your Tale: prethee ſtand
further off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Beate him enough: after a little time
Ile beate him too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand farther: Come proceede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, as I told thee, ’tis a cuſtome with him
I’th afternoone to ſleepe: there thou maiſt braine him,
Hauing firſt ſeiz’d his bookes: Or with a logge
Batter his ſkull, or paunch him with a ſtake,
Or cut his wezand with thy knife. Remember
Firſt to poſſeſſe his Bookes; for without them
Hee’s but a Sot, as I am; nor hath not
One Spirit to command: they all do hate him
As rootedly as I. Burne but his Bookes,
He ha’s braue Vtenſils (for ſo he calles them)
Which when he ha’s a houſe, hee’l decke withall.
And that moſt deeply to conſider, is
The beautie of his daughter: he himſelfe
Cals her a non-pareill: I neuer ſaw a woman
But onely Sycorax my Dam, and ſhe;
But ſhe as farre ſurpaſſeth Sycorax,
As great’ſt do’s leaſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it ſo braue a Laſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I Lord, ſhe will become thy bed, I warrant,
And bring thee forth braue brood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Monſter, I will kill this man: his daughter and
I will be King and Queene, ſaue our Graces: and Trin-
culo and thy ſelfe ſhall be Vice-royes:
Doſt thou like the plot Trinculo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me thy hand, I am ſorry I beate thee:
But while thou liu’ſt keepe a good tongue in thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Within this halfe houre will he be aſleepe,
Wilt thou deſtroy him then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I on mine honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: This will I tell my Maſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou mak’ſt me merry: I am full of pleaſure,
Let vs be iocond. Will you troule the Catch
You taught me but whileare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: At thy requeſt Monſter, I will do reaſon,
Any reaſon: Come on Trinculo, let vs ſing.
Flout ’em, and cout ’em: and ſkowt ’em, and flout ’em,
Thought is free.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s not the tune.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Ariell plaies the tune on a Tabor and Pipe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: What is this ſame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the tune of our Catch, plaid by the pic-
ture of No-body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou beeſt a man, ſhew thy ſelfe in thy likenes:
If thou beeſt a diuell, take’t aſ thou liſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: O forgiue me my ſinnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: He that dies payes all debts: I defie thee;
Mercy vpon vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou affeard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: No Monſter, not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not affeard, the Iſle is full of noyſes,
Sounds, and ſweet aires, that giue delight and hurt not:
Sometimes a thouſand twangling Inſtruments
Will hum about mine eares; and ſometime voices,
That if I then had wak’d after long ſleepe,
Will make me ſleepe againe, and then in dreaming,
The clouds methought would open, and ſhew riches
Ready to drop vpon me, that when I wak’d
I cri’de to dreame againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: This will proue a braue kingdome to me,
Where I ſhall haue my Muſicke for nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: When Proſpero is deſtroy’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhall be by and by:
I remember the ſtorie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſound is going away,
Lets follow it, and after do our worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Leade Monſter,
Wee’l follow: I would I could ſee this Taborer,
He layes it on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt come?
Ile follow Stephano.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alonso, Sebaſtian, Anthonio, Gonzallo, Adrian, Franciſco, &c.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: By’r lakin, I can goe no further, Sir,
My old bones akes: here’s a maze trod indeede
Through fourth-rights, & Meanders: by your patience,
I needes muſt reſt me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: Old Lord, I cannot blame thee,
Who, am my ſelfe attach’d with wearineſſe
To th’dulling of my ſpirits: Sit downe, and reſt:
Euen here I will put off my hope, and keepe it
No longer for my Flatterer: he is droun’d
Whom thus we ſtray to finde, and the Sea mocks
Our fruſtrate ſearch on land: well, let him goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am right glad, that he’s ſo out of hope:
Doe not for one repulſe forgoe; the purpoſe
That you reſolu’d t’effeƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: The next aduantage will we take throughly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be to night,
For now they are oppreſſ’d with trauaile, they
Will not, nor cannot vſe ſuch vigilance
As when they are freſh.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Solemne and ſtrange Muſicke: and Proſper on the top (inuiſible:) Enter ſeuerall ſtrange ſhapes, bringing in a Banket; and dance about it with gentle aƈtions of ſalutations, and inuiting the King, &c. to eate, they depart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay to night: no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: What harmony is this? my good friends, harke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Maruellous ſweet Muſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue vs kind keepers, heaués: what were theſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: A liuing Drolerie: now I will beleeue
That there are Vnicornes: that in Arabia
There is one Tree, the Phœnix throne, one Phœnix
At this houre reigning there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile beleeue both:
And what do’s elſe want credit, come to me
And Ile beſworne ’tis true: Trauellers nere did lye,
Though fooles at home condemne ’em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: If in Naples
I ſhould report this now, would they beleeue me?
If I ſhould ſay I ſaw ſuch Iſlands;
(For certes, theſe are people of the Iſland)
Who though they are of monſtrous ſhape, yet note
Their manners are more gentle, kinde, then of
Our humaine generation you ſhall finde
Many, nay almoſt any.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Honeſt Lord,
Thou haſt ſaid well: for ſome of you there preſent;
Are worſe then diuels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot too much muſe
Such ſhapes, ſuch geſture, and ſuch ſound expreſſing
(Although they want the vſe of tongue) a kinde
Of excellent dumbe diſcourſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Praiſe in departing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fr.
SPEECH.LINE: They vaniſh’d ſtrangely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: No matter, ſince
They haue left their Viands behinde; for wee haue ſtomacks.
Wilt pleaſe you taſte of what is here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith Sir, you neede not feare: when wee were Boyes
Who would beleeue that there were Mountayneeres,
Dew-lapt, like Buls, whoſe throats had hanging at ’em
Wallets of fleſh? or that there were ſuch men
Whoſe heads ſtood in their breſts? which now we finde
Each putter out of fiue for one, will bring vs
Good warrant of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſtand to, and feede,
Although my laſt, no matter, ſince I feele
The beſt is paſt: brother: my Lord, the Duke,
Stand too, and doe as we.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Thunder and Lightning. Enter Ariell (like a Harpey) claps his wings vpon the Table, and with a quient deuice the Banquet vaniſhes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: You are three men of ſinne, whom deſtiny
That hath to inſtrument this lower world,
And what is in’t: the neuer ſurfeited Sea,
Hath caus’d to belch vp you: and on this Iſland,
Where man doth not inhabit, you ’mongſt men,
Being moſt vnfit to liue: I haue made you mad;
And euen with ſuch like valour, men hang, and drowne
Their proper ſelues: you fooles, I and my fellowes
Are miniſters of Fate, the Elements
Of whom your ſwords are temper’d, may as well
Wound the loud windes, or with bemockt-at-Stabs
Kill the ſtill cloſing waters, as diminiſh
One dowle that’s in my plumbe: My fellow miniſters
Are like-invulnerable: if you could hurt,
Your ſwords are now too maſſie for your ſtrengths,
And will not be vplifted: But remember
(For that’s my buſineſſe to you) that you three
From Millaine did ſupplant good Proſpero,
Expos’d vnto the Sea (which hath requit it)
Him, and his innocent childe: for which foule deed,
The Powres, delaying (not forgetting) haue
Incens’d the Seas, and Shores; yea, all the Creatures
Againſt your peace: Thee of thy Sonne, Alonſo
They haue bereft; and doe pronounce by me
Lingring perdition (worſe then any death
Can be at once) ſhall ſtep, by ſtep attend
You, and your wayes, whoſe wraths to guard you from,
Which here, in this moſt deſolate Iſle, elſe fals
Vpon your heads, is nothing but hearts-ſorrow,
And a cleere life enſuing.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He vaniſhes in Thunder: then (to ſoft Muſicke.) Enter the ſhapes againe, and daunce (with mockes and mowes) and carrying out the Table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Brauely the figure of this Harpie, haſt thou
Perform’d (my Ariell) a grace it had deuouring:
Of my Inſtruƈtion, haſt thou nothing bated
In what thou had’ſt to ſay: ſo with good life,
And obſeruation ſtrange, my meaner miniſters
Their ſeuerall kindes haue done: my high charmes work,
And theſe (mine enemies) are all knit vp
In their diſtraƈtions: they now are in my powre;
And in theſe fits, I leaue them, while I viſit
Yong Ferdinand (whom they ſuppoſe is droun’d)
And his, and mine lou’d darling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I’th name of ſomething holy, Sir, why ſtand you
In this ſtrange ſtare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: O, it is monſtrous: monſtrous:
Me thought the billowes ſpoke, and told me of it,
The windes did ſing it to me: and the Thunder
(That deepe and dreadfull Organ-Pipe) pronounc’d
The name of Proſper: it did baſe my Treſpaſſe,
Therefore my Sonne i’th Ooze is bedded; and
I’le ſeeke him deeper then ere plummet ſounded,
And with him there lye mudded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: But one feend at a time,
Ile fight their Legions ore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be thy Second.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: All three of them are deſperate: their great guilt
(Like poyſon giuen to worke a great time after)
Now gins to bite the ſpirits: I doe beſeech you
(That are of ſuppler ioynts) follow them ſwiftly,
And hinder them from what this extaſie
May now prouoke them to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ad
SPEECH.LINE: Follow, I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: If I haue too auſterely puniſh’d you,
Your compenſation makes amends, for I
Haue giuen you here, a third of mine owne life,
Or that for which I liue: who, once againe
I tender to thy hand: All thy vexations
